title: 114_hr3319
content: The "Postal Innovation Act" may be cited as the short title. It includes provisions for expanded services. The "Postal Innovation Act" establishes a pilot program for nonpostal services through public-private partnerships in 5 postal districts, including rural areas. Services may include financial services, warehousing, experimental postal products market testing, community support services, Internet voting, and municipal broadband Internet service. The Postal Innovation Act establishes a pilot program for nonpostal services in 5 postal districts, including rural areas. Services may include financial services, warehousing, experimental postal products market testing, community support services, Internet voting, municipal broadband Internet service, public wireless Internet service, emergency broadband Internet service, and passport services. The Postmaster General must submit a report to Congress within 1 year, analyzing the pilot program and assessing cost-effective implementation of nonpostal services. The Postal Innovation Act allows the Postal Service to provide property and services to State, local, and tribal governments under agreed terms. This includes the possibility of reimbursement. The Act defines the term "State" to include all states, the District of Columbia, American Samoa, and Guam. The Postal Innovation Act allows the Postal Service to provide property and services to State, local, and tribal governments, including reimbursement. The Act defines "State" to include all states, the District of Columbia, American Samoa, Guam, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands of the United States, and any other territory or possession of the United States. The term "tribal government" refers to the government of an Indian tribe as defined in the Indian Self-Determination Act. SEC. 3. SHIPPING OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES. 411. Cooperation with other government agencies. The text discusses the mailing regulations for alcoholic beverages, specifying conditions under which they can be considered mailable. Amendments are made to sections of title 18 and title 39 of the United States Code to allow for the mailing of alcoholic beverages under certain circumstances. The Postal Service will establish regulations for mailing alcoholic beverages, ensuring direct delivery to individuals at least 21 years old with valid ID. The alcohol must not be for resale, and the shipper must certify compliance. The Postal Service requires shippers of alcoholic beverages to certify compliance with regulations and provide necessary information. The terms 'alcoholic beverage' and 'covered shipper' are defined in the subsection. The Postal Service requires certification from shippers of alcoholic beverages, who must have registration or permits from the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau or the Secretary of the Treasury. The amendments made by this section will take effect upon the issuance of regulations by the Postal Service. The amendments made by this section will take effect under section 3001(p) of title 39, United States Code, as amended, or 120 days after the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. UPGRADING THE FLEET OF THE POSTAL SERVICE. The Postmaster General may enter contracts to upgrade the postal fleet for long-term savings by reducing collision, maintenance, fuel costs. The Postal Service will review routes for vehicle upgrades to increase fuel economy, reduce collisions, and lower carbon emissions. Guidelines for this process will be developed by the Postmaster General. The Postmaster General will develop guidelines for contracted vehicles and vehicles purchased or leased by the Postal Service. These guidelines will include requirements for passenger cars to meet specific emissions and fuel economy standards. The guidelines for vehicles purchased or leased by the Postal Service include requirements for passenger cars to meet specific emissions and fuel economy standards set by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency. The guidelines for vehicles purchased or leased by the Postal Service include requirements for passenger cars to meet specific emissions and fuel economy standards set by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency. Medium-duty and heavy-duty vehicles must comply with emissions and fuel economy standards set by the EPA and the Secretary of Transportation. Safety standards must also be met for all described vehicles. The Postal Service vehicles must be equipped with crash avoidance solutions like camera-based sensors and automatic emergency braking. These standards apply to contracted vehicles and those purchased or leased after a year from the enactment of the Act. The Postmaster General is required to reduce petroleum consumption by 2% annually until fiscal year 2025. The Postmaster General can reinvest cost savings from section 2 into innovation, research, development, and Postal Service operations. Additionally, a GAO report is required. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 180 days on the feasibility of the Postal Service offering Internet services to the public, including broadband access and Internet voting. The report will include cost-effective strategies, recommendations for public interest, and an analysis of potential financial benefits.
